Blog.post: Most voters believe that Bush is a better foreign policy leader than Kerry would be. This remains a central strength for Bush and Republicans, but in my view, we still have more work to do. I wish Bush would stop operating on the defensive with respect to the war in Iraq. I fear that he's allowing 3rd parties and external events to define this issue. The plot of the Iraq war currently prevailing in the media, and thus a large proportion of the electorate, is this: Bush says SH has WMDs. Bush topples SH despite strong international opposition. No WMDs were found. The war, and the associated casualties and high costs, was unnecessary after all. But this plot is missing some key ingredients and so far, Bush is doing nothing to remind us of them and their importance. The central issue was not WMD (nor was it liberating the Iraqi people although that's a welcome by-product of the war). Rather, the justification of war was based on Iraq's decade-long defiance of countless UN demands to open their country for rigorous weapons inspections. Iraq - not the United States - defied the will of the international community. Iraq - not the U.S. - did not cooperate diplomatically and prudently. The U.N. failed and Iraq failed to live up to its responsibilities - regardless of which particular WMDs were or were not in Iraq by the time the coalition forces showed up in Baghdad. Bush should remind us again and again that in the post-9/11 world, we simply cannot allow dictatorial regimes to defy the will of the world, especially those countries that have histories of WMD and ties to terrorism. International security requires institutions like the U.N. to have meaning, for its words and will to carry weight. The central reason the existence of such institutions as the U.N. is to reduce the uncertainty associated with countries fending for themselves in all matters and to create an opportunity for the expression of a cohesive international will on certain matters, including international security. If the work of the U.N. does not effectively reduce this uncertainty (such as passing resolution after resolution with no binding action for over a decade) or is incapable of coercing outlaw regimes to heed international will, then leaders like the United States must carry the burden of resolving the threat posed by countries that defy international will. America, as the world's sole superpower, must bear this responsibility because it is the only country capable of doing so. In terms of weapons of mass destruction, the point is that we don't know for sure what specific countries have or don't have unless the international system of weapons inspections works. If the U.N. is working, no American president should be stupid enough after 9/11 to sit idly by and hope the situation improves without taking some kind of concrete action. Bush should remind voters about Resolution 1441 and that its vote in the U.N. was unanimous and binding. That resoultion pertained directly to SH's defiance and indirectly to the presence or absence of particular weapons. I think this focus would resonate with those who are concerned about the casualties in Iraq but who still lean toward Bush over Kerry when it comes to dealing with the new realities of terrorism on American soil. P.S. Bush should also remind us about one by-product of his tough stance against Iraqi defiance - Libya's willingness to give up its weapons.

urlLink Our friends on the Left routinely remind us that the Right includes unsavory figures such as Ann Coulter and Rush Limbaugh whose rhetoric does nothing to raise the level of public discourse in our country. Limbaugh-Coulter-Hannity-haters often make good points about how these figures merely rattle off meaningless diatribes and make accusations with flimsy evidence (e.g. Vince Foster and Ron Brown were murdered). But in fact, those on the Left don't hate Coulter et al. because their invectives are anathema to democracy or free exchange of ideas or civic progress or a “responsible” discussion of the “issues” that matter, etc. Rather, they hate them for their political beliefs. If flimsy evidence and loose-cannon rhetoric were the real reason for the Left’s hatred of Coulter and company, the Left would equally hate - and certainly not embrace - people like Michael Moore and Mark Crispin Miller on the Left (the former making a mountain out of a b.s. mole hill re: links between Bush and the Saudis and the latter claiming that Bush team took no action on intelligence warnings pre-9/11 because it "chose to let those horrors happen for its own political advantage."). But the Left doesn't hate these people. To the contrary, they embrace them with open arms. urlLink Krugman dances around an outright endorsement of Moore, suggesting that he performs an "essential service") by making some good points. But since when did making a good point or two give one legitimate license to whip up some b.s. rumors and spin them out as responsible documentary history? Once in awhile, even Ann Coulter and Rush Limbaugh make good points, but this doesn't excuse their underlying nutiness. Krugman's support of Moore is based on his belief that the media haven't been doing their job. But the idea of responsible journalism is that unlike Moore, reporters are supposed to actually gather facts and examine evidence before they can earn widespread acclaim and win major awards. Well beyond Krugman, top leaders of the Democratic Party have joined in the Moore bandwagon. Terry McAuliffe and Senate Democratic leader Tom Daschle have publicly celebrated Moore by appearing at the premier of F-11. If this isn't an endorsement, I don't know what is. To be fair, some on the Left have been critical of Moore. urlLink Christopher Hitchens does offer a good critique, and here's an excerpt: To describe this film [F-11] as dishonest and demagogic would almost be to promote those terms to the level of respectability. To describe this film as a piece of crap would be to run the risk of a discourse that would never again rise above the excremental. To describe it as an exercise in facile crowd-pleasing would be too obvious. Fahrenheit 9/11 is a sinister exercise in moral frivolity, crudely disguised as an exercise in seriousness. It is also a spectacle of abject political cowardice masking itself as a demonstration of "dissenting" bravery. At the end of the day, the Left's outrage about Hannity and Coulter and Limbaugh et al. is outrage of a political - not moral – flavor. This is fine, but they should abandon their self-serving feigned outrage-rhetoric suggesting that underlying their constant criticisms of Limbaugh et al. is some kind of moral high-ground idealism and just acknowledge that their dissent with these figures is based on fundamental political disagreements and nothing more.

“Oh my gosh, dude, I just saw him!” I said. “Who?” Asked Stew. “The soup nazi. He just got out of a car and walked right by me on the street. He didn’t really look like the soup nazi, but it was definitely him.” I was on the phone with a leading member of a national power-broker syndicate. But now, I hung up and walked back inside the Baja Fresh…toward a destiny of fame… I saw Heather get introduced to the Soup Nazi by the director. But they walked away before I got all the way inside. I didn’t want to seem over-eager. I didn’t want to just walk up and say, Hi, I’m [capshine]. I’d hang back and wait for just the right moment. That’s what BC would do. I worked the crowd. Said hi to some folks. Meandered my way over to SN. Eventually, I was standing next to him. I smiled, he smiled back. He went to get a Coke, and I sat down at a nearby table. He came back and sat at the table right next to me. I looked over and said, “hi, I’m [capshine].” He shook my hand and said it was nice to meet me. He didn’t introduce himself. Then I looked over again and said, “So, are you enjoying our nation’s freaking capital?” That line was a big gamble. It was going to be a reject or a slam dunk. “Oh, yeah, I should have brought my son though and made more of a trip out of this. He’s never been here before.” – SN. “Well, speaking of firsts, I’ve never been in a commercial before.” – me. “Oh, it’s alright. It is a lot of work just to make a little bit of film though. It’s kind of crazy that you work for 8-10 hours for something and it gets turned into 30 seconds of video.” – SN. By this time I was noticing his mannerisms and accent and tone of voice were not at all like the soup nazi on tv. Weird. It really is acting. He went on to tell me about some other commercials he’d been in and that he’d been in a episode of Scrubs, and that they had cut a lot of the filming in that show also. He also said that the only show he’d ever done where they kept most every shot they cut was…SEINFELD. Later someone pointed out to me that I should have said, at this point, “oh you were on Seinfeld.” But that didn’t occur to me at the time. Anyway, he was the first to raise the subject of Seinfeld. He talked about it a little bit. He mentioned it was frustrating to be known for one part in one show 9 years ago (can you believe it was that long ago?!?!). Up to this point, it was just me and him talking. One to one with the Soup Nazi! But then some other people started to drift up, including the director of the commercial and H. SN told the director he was hungry and asked if there was any place he could walk to for something to eat. The director said he’s send someone out. “Well, we can send someone up to the Silver Diner [where I once dined with Stew]. They have sandwiches, burgers, and…soup…no pun intended” – H. “haha…NO SOUP FOR ME!!!” – SN. We all laughed. It was going to be an amusing night. It was also going to be a long night. The details of the shoot are not too interesting. The sum of it all is that 2 slices of pizza, 6 Reeces’ cups and 1 coke later it was 3:30 AM and I bugged out. Ugh. Another Ugh is that I don’t think you’re even going to be able to see me in this commercial even though I was sitting right next to the Soup Nazi as he was acting. But they pull the camera so close in for the shots, you really can’t see anything around the subject. I might be in the picture for a minute at the beginning when the show the whole room. Other than that, I really don’t have high hopes. The premise of the commercial is that the soup nazi is a sort of food cop, symbolic of the government who stands at the front of a line in a fast food joint and tells people what they can eat based on their weight. It looks like it could be pretty funny and memorable. I’ll let you know if I find out any info on when and where it’s going to air.

From the NYT article Stew sent me this morning: "I'll try to continue farming, but there's now the allure of getting out with a little bit of dignity," said Mr. Pridgen, 59, who said he expected to receive about $202,000 from a buyout. "This is just compensation for someone like myself who's spent the last 40 years farming. It gives me a little more hope." Let me get this straight, this guy worked his whole life growing tobacco and he needs a tobacco buyout to get "just compensation"? What about the money he made selling tobacco all these years? One part of what I find frustrating about the tobacco buyout is the sense that somehow tobacco farmers have been doing our world this great favor by growing tobacco all these years and that now we ought to be paying them back. Sure it's good for people to have jobs, but: 1. Arguably, smoking causes more harm than good in our society - prooducing a net economic drag associated with health care costs 2. Tobacco companies can buy tobacco more cheaply abroad 3. Why are people entitled to government re-distribution of wealth? Am I missing something here? Are tobacco farmers really some kind of benevolent society that has been helping us for all these years without compensation? If they didn't feel like they were getting fairly compensated for what they were doing, why didn't they do something else? Indeed, many of them did, which is why they left farming and the quota has gotten concentrated in the hands of fewer larger outfits. I've also heard a lot of talk about how Burr needs to work on a tobacco buyout in order to appeal to people "down east". But will enough voters be pleased enough to vote for a candidate based on buyout support? Will this bloc of voters make a difference in the election? How big of a voting bloc are these farmers, anyway? Potential paper topic, Stew? Certainly people from my part of the state are suspicious of a buyout and would probably considering voting against a candidate for supporting it. I certainly would, depending on how the buyout was financed.

From the entrance, the civil war battlefield at Sharpsburg looked like a brightly lit stained-glass window. It was a bright blue panel over a shimmering green panel. The battle of Sharpsburg took place in 3 stages, and so did our tour on Saturday. First the video stage. We viewed an ancient movie narrated by James Earl Jones that explained the context and development of the battle. One video had Monty Python-esque scenes of man after man getting shot in the face and spurting blood. Apparently all wounds at Sharpsburg were head wounds. After that we went around the battlefield for about 4 hours. Most of the time, I was having an off and on intellectual conversation with some bearded sage in our group. It left me longing for a trip to the old Carolina Coffee Shop (not the remodeled one). As we stood at a shallow ditch where a line of confederates held back a yankee assault of thousands for hours, I realized that in spite of the video and map and introduction by the park staff, I have no appreciation for the scope and layout of the battle that day. About that time, a random guy came up to one fellow in our party - who happened to be black - and said, "you know, this was all for you, right?" Stew, this reminds me of your Pearl Harbor story from the bus in Boone. I hope you will re-tell it to us in the comments. Phase 3 of our tour was surreal: We walked to the top of a 60' tower in the middle of the battlefield. For an hour, we stayed in the top of this tower, which was an area of maybe 12' x 12', taking pictures, talking, admiring the brigh blue sky and the shimmering green grass bending in the wind. We watched a storm blow by miles to the south and saw its rain falling like a blurry gray sheet hanging from the sky. We were on the world, but not of it. The earth turned beneath us. By the way, I'm converting to Eastern Orthodox.

"I am the light that is over all things...Split a piece of wood; I am there. Lift up the stone, and you will find me there." Gospel of Thomas # 77. Just 5 minutes from my house, right along the Potomac runs the Potomac Heritage Trail. The trail was my weekend. There's only like 4 people per mile there and none of them are weird homeless dudes, like you'll find in Rock Creek Park or the C&O Canal. It's just crowded enough not to seem sketchy, but enough solitude that you can find a nice place to ponder the meaning of life, which I did. 60 feet of rock spilling from the GW parkway over a period of decades marks the entrance to a rock wonderland. After passing this demolished entrance to the trail, I walked for miles alongside soaring cliffs, periodically dissected by streams flowing down to the river. At one point, I heard loud crackling deep in the woods and sensed a large cliff nearby. I crept my way through the dense forest and saw the gray of stone materialize from behind snaking green vines. I approached a large cliff that was crumbling down a big hill. It looked like it had been crumbling this way for many years. I scrambled over the preamble of bolders and felt the cool air blowing off the crackling water as it poured down the rocks. At the top of the cliff, I saw a hollowed out throne of rock - the source of the trickling stream seeking its way through the bolders down this hill. I climbed to it. A 30 foot sheer, smooth rock wall like the back of a seat, clad in a sheet of water was at the top of this stream. Kneeling at the bottom of this rock, in front of the falling water, I saw the past, present, and future flowing by as one entity. Isaiah must have secreted himself in some place like this when the fire and wind and earthquake passed before God at the mountain at Horeb. He must have found solace between tons of stone that could crush him any second.

A friend of mine shared this with me, and I wanted to pass it along: I know it's been a long time since I've had any new lingo for any of you guys, but I've recently stumbled upon this great new African American phenomenon that I wanted to share with you. It's called a "babymom." Now keep in mind, my research into this entity is still in the preliminary stages, but from what I can gather, "babymom" appears to be a simple contraction of the common English phrase "baby's mom" or "baby's mother." This term is used to refer to any woman who has conceived of and given birth to one of your children, but who is neither your wife nor your girlfriend. For example, "I was at my babymom's yesterday..." or "His babymom work at Walgreen's..." The 's' in the middle is always silent, and any further slurring or truncating of the phrase such as "babyma" is allowed and, in fact, encouraged. So far I've come into contact with this phrase only twice. The first time was when one of my young black patients came in with concerns that he may have an STD. He was wondering whether he may have gotten it from, or passed it on to, any of his partners including (but not limited to) his current girlfriend and his babymom. The second instance was last night in the emergency room, when a blood-soaked 30-some year old black man was carried in by his friend after having been shot in the buttocks outside of the ER (next to the parking lot where I park my car, incidentally). In relating his story to the police, the friend explained that they had been hanging out at the victim's "babymom place," sitting on the porch, when the victim's ex-girlfriend's boyfriend came up with a gun and shot at him as payback for a prior altercation. I'll keep you posted as I unravel more of the tale of this exciting new discovery! In the meantime, feel free to begin incorporating "babymom" into your own dialogue, wherever you may find it useful... Ever in your service on the front lines of the great racial divide, --Gabriel

This urlLink article is one of many critical indictments of charter schools that only casually and somewhat indirectly mentions what is the central point. Students whose parents move them out of traditional public schools into charter schools do so for a reason - either there is something perceived to be bad at their 'old' schools or they believe there is something desirable about charter schools. Further, many charters come about solely to serve "at risk" students, so comparing charter test scores to traditional public school test scores is misleading at best. From a research design perspective, what is needed is to treat students as units of analysis (not schools) and randomly assigning equivalent students to charters and to traditional schools and tracking their performance over time with repeated equivalent measures. Absent this, be very suspicious about these kinds of voodoo reports because charter kids are by definition not equivalent to the larger public school population. Public education is fraught with problems - not the least of which is that they are immune from the competitive pressures of the market. Ineffective teachers are very hard to fire or demote yet receive the same pay as "teachers-of-the-year". Pay is low, mitigating the ample supply of talented labor. Discipline is a major problem and the 'behaviorally challenged' consume significant school resources. No Child Left Behind has some market-like incentive structures but they are school- (not teacher-) based. So the idiot teachers who are teachers because they have no other labor market options are lumped in with the high-achieving, inspirational, and innovative teachers. Plus there are too many administrators and in my view, too few parents willing to play an active role in the education of their children. A mess.

Big Pharma spends like $35 billion on R&D per year. My first question is, if stem cells have such promise for curing diseases, why aren't more profit-seeking R&D firms doing lots more of it? If they're not, is it because they don't believe the probability of success is worth the extraordinary cost and risk? Is there some special reason that the market is not an appropriate indicator of untapped profit opportunities here? Anyway, why are we waiting around for government to do this research? The second question/comment pertains to the ethical questions surrounding stem cells. The aspect of the JK's political stem cell position that is most disingenuous is that he presents what is ultimately a false choice. Surely he is not suggesting (is he?) that there should be no ethical bounds on human scientific activity for the sake of searching for cures. After all, we all agree that Alzheimers is terrible and its cure highly desirable, but at what ethical cost? What are the tradeoffs? JK's rhetoric conveniently leaves no room for discussion of what these ethical limits should be. I am more than a little frightened by a guy who says he believes that life begins at conception (when talking to the Sunday congregation) but who nonethless breathlessly laments GB's essentially moderate, pro-life position on stem cell research. In championing (and probably exaggerating) the potential of stem cell research, he conveniently avoids discussion of what explicit ethical framework that he believes should guide this kind of controversial research. JK's view would simply force taxpayers - many of whom find cultivating and destroying human embryos unconscionable - to pay for this research. Should we use public funds to clone embryos in the name of research, too? Where is the line, JK? If you want to make an issue about this research, then share with us your position on where (and whether) ethical lines should be drawn. What is off limits? The ethics of stem cell research does not present easy questions for either side. For example, those of us with ethical/moral reservations about harvesting embryos in the name of research really need to learn more about the ethics of legal in vitro fertilization techniques that discard embryos.
